title: Lafonia
text:
Lafonia is a <a href="peninsula">peninsula</a> forming the southern part of <a href="East%20Falkland">East Falkland</a>, the largest of the <a href="Falkland%20Islands">Falkland Islands</a>.
Geography and geology.
Shaped like the letter "E", it is joined to the northern part of the island by an <a href="isthmus">isthmus</a> that is almost wide. Were this isthmus to be severed, Lafonia would be the third largest of the Falkland Islands. <a href="Falkland%20Sound">Falkland Sound</a> runs to the west between Lafonia and <a href="West%20Falkland">West Falkland</a>. <a href="Choiseul%20Sound">Choiseul Sound</a> divides Lafonia from the northern part of East Falkland, which is still unnamed.
<a href="Barren%20Island%20%28Falkland%20Islands%29">Barren Island</a>, <a href="Bleaker%20Island">Bleaker Island</a>, <a href="George%20Island">George Island</a>, <a href="Lively%20Island">Lively Island</a>, <a href="Sea%20Lion%20Island">Sea Lion Island</a> and <a href="Speedwell%20Island">Speedwell Island</a> are all off Lafonia.
The geology of north west Lafonia is <a href="Permian">Permian</a>, and similar to that of parts of <a href="Ecca%20Pass">Ecca Pass</a> in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>. The plain of Lafonia is constituted by arenaceous sediments of the Lafonia Group. Depressions in the sediments formed where they were cut vertically by basalt dikes.
In the 21st century, Lafonia has seen gold prospecting by Falkland Gold and Minerals Ltd.
History and population.
The land is gentle and low-lying, but almost uninhabited, falling into the "<a href="Camp%20%28Falkland%20Islands%29">camp</a>" category. Most of its settlement occurred in the mid 19th century.
In 1845, Mr <a href="Samuel%20Fisher%20Lafone">Samuel Fisher Lafone</a>, a wealthy cattle and hide merchant on the <a href="R%C3%ADo%20de%20la%20Plata">river Plate</a>, obtained from government a grant of the southern portion of the East Falkland, which was a peninsula in extent, and possession of all the wild cattle on the island for a period of six years, for a payment of £10,000 down, and £20,000 in ten years from January 1, 1852. In 1851, Mr Lafone's interest in Lafonia, as the peninsula came to be called, was purchased for £30,000 by the <a href="Falkland%20Islands%20Company">Falkland Islands Company</a>, which had been incorporated by charter in the same year.
Lafonia has been used for <a href="sheep%20farming">sheep farming</a> since the early nineteenth century. It is run from <a href="Darwin%2C%20Falkland%20Islands">Darwin</a> (founded 1859) and <a href="Goose%20Green">Goose Green</a>, both of which are located on the narrow isthmus that separates Lafonia from the rest of East Falkland. <a href="North%20Arm%20Settlement">North Arm Settlement</a> is the only substantial settlement in Lafonia (not counting offshore islands), along with <a href="Walker%20Creek%20%28Falkland%20Islands%29">Walker Creek</a>. Attractions include the <a href="Bodie%20Suspension%20Bridge">Bodie Suspension Bridge</a>, built in 1925 and said to be the southernmost in the world. There is also a shop here. <a href="Listed%20buildings%20in%20the%20Falkland%20Islands">Listed buildings</a> in Lafonia include The Galpon and Stone Corral in Darwin, The Stone Cottage and Goose Green Hall (owned by Falklands Landholdings) in Goose Green and Paragon House.
The first battles on land during the <a href="Falklands%20War">Falklands War</a> took place on Lafonia (see <a href="Battle%20of%20Goose%20Green">Battle of Goose Green</a>), where over a thousand <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> personnel were stationed and around one-hundred locals were imprisoned in the community hall. The area is now home to an <a href="Argentine%20Military%20Cemetery">Argentine Military Cemetery</a>. Parts of Lafonia, especially near Darwin and Goose Green, are still heavily mined.
Other settlements include Port King, Egg Harbour and the abandoned <a href="Hope%20Place">Hope Place</a>.
Wildlife.
<a href="Charles%20Darwin">Charles Darwin</a> surveyed the area's <a href="wildlife">wildlife</a> during his now-famous voyage on <a href="HMS%20Beagle">HMS "Beagle"</a>.
Lafonia's wildlife includes the <a href="Chilo%C3%A9%20wigeon">Chiloé wigeon</a>, <a href="silver%20teal">silver teal</a> and <a href="yellow-billed%20pintail">yellow-billed pintail</a>. Introduced <a href="brown%20trout">brown trout</a> are found in at least one stream flowing into <a href="Choiseul%20Sound">Choiseul Sound</a>. There is also a population of <a href="zebra%20trout">zebra trout</a>.
